post.body:
We all know that for a while, search engines (most famously Google) have started changing their algorithm to promote the content they want you to see, which makes it extremely hard to find what you're looking for. Even websites with their own search engines, like social media and news sites, are doing this.

However, it seems that I'm literally the only shithead on Earth who is affected by this. Everyone else can still immediately find what they're looking for, even if it's buried on some obscure site or post that never shows up in any search results. When I spend 2 hours and come back with 1-2 things, everyone else can still find 731208560478534718232524 things per second. It's like they have some kind of telepathic ability to just pluck the links to what they want out of thin air.

One example is posting pictures. I created +foxes, and have trouble finding enough content because I can only search google images, reddit, and imgur. However, many posters could easily find multiple pics or videos from a variety of buried social media posts and extremely-little-known websites. They do this from tons of different sources, all the time.

Another example is news stories. Everyone except me can find about 100 cool news stories (or politicians' comments) per hour the nanosecond they come out, just by "looking" for them. Well I also look for them, and only ever find the very top, trending stories, that everyone has already seen. There is no way to find anything else other than pure luck, so I don't know what kind of magic you all are using.

So, search engines are basically useless now. So how does everyone still find everything online, and why does everyone always try to sidestep that question when I ask them (as if I'm not supposed to know for some reason)?

parent.body:
Another thing you can do, that i've done... is have two separate browsers.  One for everything, like shitposting and checking mail, etc.

And another without ANY LOGIN INFO WHATSOEVER.  No cookies, no third party cookies, no location, no camera, etc.  Block fucking everything you can so the browser is not recognizable.  

THEN, do your searches...  also, you should probably use Brave, or even Opera.  AND DON'T USE DUCKDUCKGO.  That shit is garbage disguised and marketed as some sort of censorship free shit.

parent.body:
no one always gets the results they're searching for, I rarely get them; but then again, if I cant find it in english, I'll use my other language to find something, this tends to give me more (sometimes less) results. I guess people know different sources that may give them their results, and they search for/in that place. 

I mainly only use petsnails and 4chan for pictures so I cant really say anything for other sources, however I just stumble across them. petsnails is a forum for people with pet snails, I have pet snails, therefore when I was searching for things relating to them, i.e proper care, species, diseases etc, I found the forum. and I can imagine theres forums for all kinds of pets, like foxes- people keep foxes as pets. maybe searching for a fox forum might help somewhat? for 4chan (I use like I use ruqqus), /an/ is where I get my animal and land pictures, today i discovered a thread for fox pictures, some of which I havent seen before, and I saved some of them.

so really, you tend to just stumble across things, wether that be from someone telling you about it, or you finding it searching for something. I doubt people always find the source, it's usually that someone stumbles across the source and then spreads the source that then reach your ears

Yeah, some of them could tone it down a little, but just restricted to quality stuff they still find *WAY* more in an hour than I ever could in a year. And not all of them just copy & paste everything. Lukginzis for example almost all his posts are good quality, and there are like 100 of them per hour. Meanwhile I can't even find 10 crappy ones in 2 hours.

And the posters in +foxes knew of every fox pic and video on the whole internet, and every place to find them, and how to find new ones the second they come into existence. Me? I don't know a single fucking thing aside from a few things others have told me.

Every time I ask these people how they do it, they always sidestep the question and avoid actually answering. Even people who know me and like me. It's like everyone is hiding things from me.

post.body:
We all know that for a while, search engines (most famously Google) have started changing their algorithm to promote the content they want you to see, which makes it extremely hard to find what you're looking for. Even websites with their own search engines, like social media and news sites, are doing this.

However, it seems that I'm literally the only shithead on Earth who is affected by this. Everyone else can still immediately find what they're looking for, even if it's buried on some obscure site or post that never shows up in any search results. When I spend 2 hours and come back with 1-2 things, everyone else can still find 731208560478534718232524 things per second. It's like they have some kind of telepathic ability to just pluck the links to what they want out of thin air.

One example is posting pictures. I created +foxes, and have trouble finding enough content because I can only search google images, reddit, and imgur. However, many posters could easily find multiple pics or videos from a variety of buried social media posts and extremely-little-known websites. They do this from tons of different sources, all the time.

Another example is news stories. Everyone except me can find about 100 cool news stories (or politicians' comments) per hour the nanosecond they come out, just by "looking" for them. Well I also look for them, and only ever find the very top, trending stories, that everyone has already seen. There is no way to find anything else other than pure luck, so I don't know what kind of magic you all are using.

So, search engines are basically useless now. So how does everyone still find everything online, and why does everyone always try to sidestep that question when I ask them (as if I'm not supposed to know for some reason)?

body:
Search engines never give me many different results, no matter how I change the terms. Everyone else just seems to have an index of all the pictures and videos of something in existence, seemingly sortable by how cool or mundane it is too.

> I usually go to forums such as petsnails or 4chan. I've never really used imgur to find pictures, only to upload them, mostly because I've found that it's just the same over and over again, which you're having trouble with.

Yeah, but then how do you find all these places in the first place, when search engines never show them? I know of a few places now that other users have told me, but that's still only as good as those few sources, not how they discover them. And it also doesn't explain how people just find every post on generic social media like twitter or something.
body_html:
Search engines never give me many different results, no matter how I change the terms. Everyone else just seems to have an index of all the pictures and videos of something in existence, seemingly sortable by how cool or mundane it is too.

I usually go to forums such as petsnails or 4chan. I've never really used imgur to find pictures, only to upload them, mostly because I've found that it's just the same over and over again, which you're having trouble with.

Yeah, but then how do you find all these places in the first place, when search engines never show them? I know of a few places now that other users have told me, but that's still only as good as those few sources, not how they discover them. And it also doesn't explain how people just find every post on generic social media like twitter or something.

I always use a lot of different search terms to get to what I want, that is if I cant find anything with just one. sometimes i get hits, sometimes i don't. I may even switch browsers to see if it yields different results. oh, and I search in my native language and english because they always give me different results :)

if I'm searching for pictures though, like snails or foxes, I usually go to forums such as petsnails or 4chan. I've never really used imgur to find pictures, only to upload them, mostly because I've found that it's just the same over and over again, which you're having trouble with.

and I can't really say anything about news (sorry) as I dont really follow them; it just makes me depressed

I find that it really boils down to how you use your search engine in terms of vocabulary. I hope I'm of any help?

guild.name: News

post.body:
Posting Guidelines

#1. Things that are presented as News should be stated like a fact in the Headline. 

In the sense, Headline: X happened or X said this. 

Example: "Disney buys ABC." "New York Times Says It Will Out Blogger, Causing Him To Shutter His Website." "Truck Drivers Say They Will Not Deliver to Dangerous Far Left Cities with Defunded Police Departments". 

It can have an opinion in it "X says this isn't great," but them saying that is a relevant fact making it News. If you are posting it in News is should be notable to everyone's interest. 

A Headline may be changed, for example to more accurately reflect what the body of the article claims or add a quote. 

#2. Personal slant or commentary should go in the comments. News should try and present neutrally to be fair. Let people form their own conclusions or post in sub that is opinionated. No: "Headline‚Äîand this is why this is dumb."  This is News not Conclusions. Commentary shows giving opinions on news are not News. To be News, it should be reporting. 

If it's News but is more an opinion piece please add [Opinion] in the title, or post in +OpinionPieces 

Some types of News may be more worth a focused discussion in +politics or a specific political guild or other topic based guild. News should be noteworthy (legislation, law& justice, etc.), the arena of political petty verbal spats is more for +politics. But this is more of a suggestion. Political content is of course News. But I'm encouraging the community to not make News heavy on the minute of politics and post that in +politics. 

EDIT 07/15/20: #3. No screenshots; provide a link, provide a source.

Other related guilds: +media_criticism +fakenews +nottheonion +satire

The Guildmasters will not decide the credibility or accuracy of the News, posts will not be kicked for reporting falsehoods or lies. Up to your discretion. 

---

EDIT 08/23/20: Nothing above has changed. Forgotten clarification: No users will ever be exiled from this guild. 

EDIT 09/25/20: to clarify within this post what is already in the side bar: Commentary content like discussion, opinion, and commentary talk shows are not News. 

EDIT 07/05/21: for archival purposes: post for applying to become new GMs: https://ruqqus.com/+News/post/ce8o/news-will-now-be-accepting-applications and post welcoming the new guildmasters: https://ruqqus.com/+News/post/chit/welcome-to-the-incoming-guildmasters-of

I will.

They claim to be indwelled and guided by God's spirit, and to personally know Jesus of Nazareth when they are willful idolaters. They just can't stop lying and contradicting themselves.

Prove to me how. This is your accusation, and you haven't proved it.

The poster I replied to also -- when on the subject of miracles -- claimed to have experienced (in reality it's probably a second, third or fourth hand account) someone that has an inoperable tumour with "tentacles" all over the brain, but when doctors operated it wrapped itself up to a neat ball to be removed. He also claims to be a devout Christian, but worships a wordly empire above the tenets of his own faith, as is typical of politico-religious American Evangelicalism.

Unfortunately this is a real problem. But it only goes as far as certain people, not the faith itself.

body:
Oh, and I forgot to mention:

* They were planning on having "trusted users" who could help moderate the site by taking down rule-breaking content and banning users. Basically low-tier admin abilities. And I don't think it's hard to figure out *who* they would've given that to either. And get this: after I brought it up, they denied that it was ever a thing, and then reworded it on github so it wasn't clear what they meant. Then I continued pointing out that they had changed it and linked to the old commit, so they reworded it again and then actually rebased to make it look like the first rewording was done long before it actually was (It now says the original was changed in February, but I saw it as the current version multiple times in August).

parent.body:
>In +PoliticalCompassMemes afaik you could probably become a GM if you just ask, but I'd recommend being an active member first.

Already a GM and active user there. 

>I wouldn't say elections, that's too complicated. 

You're probably right about that one. I still think that we should at least look into the prospect, and potentially try it out on a smaller scale on the Comet Discord. 

>I would say just get rid of the stupid mod limit, anyone who isn't going to do anything bad with their mod powers and is interested should be able to become one. On reddit "we don't need any more mods" was always the excuse when someone who isn't a defaultmods member wanted to mod anywhere *proceeds to invite a few more default mods as mods*.

I wouldn't be against the idea of lots of GMs, but it increases the potential for AHStards trying to infiltrate the guild and also makes it more likely some kind of vandalism will occur. IMO, you want the mod team to be comprised of trusted individuals and not just open it up to anyone. I do agree with your assessment about the defaultmods cabal using the excuse of "we don't need any more mods" to prevent non-default mods from entry, and we certainly don't want that to happen. Making it difficult to become a mod is a great way for an "upper class" of moderators to emerge, and the "lower class" of users to be prevented from having any say in what the mods do. 

>I've seen it happen in subs not run by powermods with their own circles too, and the ruqqus admins have been acting the same way. A less common but still frequent excuse is "you're not experienced enough and/or can't be trusted" because you don't mod something of theirs already--even though you can't get modded to anything in the first place.

Can you provide some examples of this mentality among Ruqqus mods and admins? I don't use the Ruqqus Discord at all, so I'm sort of out of the loop when it comes to things like this.
parent.body_html:
In +PoliticalCompassMemes afaik you could probably become a GM if you just ask, but I'd recommend being an active member first.

Already a GM and active user there.

I wouldn't say elections, that's too complicated.

You're probably right about that one. I still think that we should at least look into the prospect, and potentially try it out on a smaller scale on the Comet Discord.

I would say just get rid of the stupid mod limit, anyone who isn't going to do anything bad with their mod powers and is interested should be able to become one. On reddit "we don't need any more mods" was always the excuse when someone who isn't a defaultmods member wanted to mod anywhere proceeds to invite a few more default mods as mods.

I wouldn't be against the idea of lots of GMs, but it increases the potential for AHStards trying to infiltrate the guild and also makes it more likely some kind of vandalism will occur. IMO, you want the mod team to be comprised of trusted individuals and not just open it up to anyone. I do agree with your assessment about the defaultmods cabal using the excuse of "we don't need any more mods" to prevent non-default mods from entry, and we certainly don't want that to happen. Making it difficult to become a mod is a great way for an "upper class" of moderators to emerge, and the "lower class" of users to be prevented from having any say in what the mods do.

I've seen it happen in subs not run by powermods with their own circles too, and the ruqqus admins have been acting the same way. A less common but still frequent excuse is "you're not experienced enough and/or can't be trusted" because you don't mod something of theirs already--even though you can't get modded to anything in the first place.

Can you provide some examples of this mentality among Ruqqus mods and admins? I don't use the Ruqqus Discord at all, so I'm sort of out of the loop when it comes to things like this.

body:
> it increases the potential for AHStards trying to infiltrate the guild and also makes it more likely some kind of vandalism will occur.

So do elections. Actually with a lot of mods it would be easier to revert the changes and kick the infiltrators.

> IMO, you want the mod team to be comprised of trusted individuals and not just open it up to anyone.

Yes of course, they should be able to be trusted, making brand new users mods doesn't make sense.

> Can you provide some examples of this mentality among Ruqqus mods and admins? I don't use the Ruqqus Discord at all, so I'm sort of out of the loop when it comes to things like this.

Basically there's a couple of users the admins just decided are their divine golden children. Most of my friends here are in that group, but the admins *hate* me, which makes it a bit personal for me. But in any case:

* They absolutely refuse to allow active members of the discord who are interested in modding it become mods. The current mods were just straight up invited by the admins when they decided to add mods. They just picked who they liked and are very exclusive about who's good enough to work with them. Basically, if they didn't ask you, you're out. They always say "we don't need any more mods". The only exception was that they did have mod apps at one point, but they decided to get rid of it almost immediately and only let *two* new mods on the team, who were of course also some of their favorite users. So basically, the mod application was a scam to "prove" that they're being fair about it.

The discord mod thing, however, is merely a symptom of a much greater problem. The admins show this favoritism elsewhere too. The badges were one example, but also:

* Who are the GMs of guilds that the admins run (+WatchRedditDie, +BetaFeedback, +Technology, a few others I can't remember)? You guessed it! Most of these were appointed before becoming discord mods...so it proves that the admins were already biased towards them when they were added. The admins are also very exclusive about who's allowed to GM stuff with them, but it took zero effort for the current ones to be invited.

* Whenever anyone else creates a meta-guild, the admins make sure to brush it off because they're not good enough for that in their eyes.

* The admins pretty much create whatever channels the mods want in the discord server

* The admins always make sure to award earned roles to mods and soon-to-be-mods in the discord server, but others rarely get them.

* They give the mods more than just moderating privileges on the discord, including: the right to see deleted channels, the right to send messages in channels without earning the required roles, the right to see deleted and even edit versions of messages (security risk), access to private logs detailing the admins' actions, a private chat with the admins where they are told about things the rest of us aren't, the right to bypass slowmode filters, banned words, etc, and I'm sure a lot more stuff. This is intentional, and they see it fit because the mods apparently deserve more than others because of their status.

* The admins become *extremely angry and defensive* when you dare criticize this holy caste system of theirs. And I mean they get fucking triggered, at least cap and ark. They even removed the reddit nazi reaction from the server because I used it to call them out on this.

body:
Obama pushed for standardized testing until his last year of presidency, and that's when he passed ESSA: https://www.vox.com/2015/10/29/9638652/standardized-tests-obama-duncan

Hillary Clinton didn't like the tests either, but she was a big exception and it was her party that pushed for them: https://www.usnews.com/opinion/knowledge-bank/articles/2016-04-11/hillary-clinton-is-wrong-on-school-standardized-testing

Trump openly opposed common core, including making more cuts to standardized testing: https://archive.thinkprogress.org/trump-signs-bill-undermining-school-accountability-f6955ab0acc5/

But his more recent comments in March implies he has changed his mind.

But in my experience, almost everyone opposes these tests on both sides.

Obama pushed for standardized testing until his last year of presidency, and that's when he passed ESSA: https://www.vox.com/2015/10/29/9638652/standardized-tests-obama-duncan

Hillary Clinton didn't like the tests either, but she was a big exception and it was her party that pushed for them: https://www.usnews.com/opinion/knowledge-bank/articles/2016-04-11/hillary-clinton-is-wrong-on-school-standardized-testing

Trump openly opposed common core, including making more cuts to standardized testing: https://archive.thinkprogress.org/trump-signs-bill-undermining-school-accountability-f6955ab0acc5/

But his more recent comments in March implies he has changed his mind.

But in my experience, almost everyone opposes these tests on both sides.

parent.body:
Ah, so I knew that Bush put through No Child Left Behind which was in response to reports of the United States graduating people who could barely read. So the idea that there would be a standard you had to reach in order to graduate stems from that. Now, Obama actually championed ESEA which was supposed to repeal testing but it didn't. 
I didn't know that one of Trump's campaign promises was to eliminate the testing. And I'm of two minds when it comes to testing. On the one hand I think that the SAT is a valuable tool for college readiness. On the other hand I think that the amount of testing that is done in grade schools is completely overboard. Currently, kids are tested three times a year, I think, and the issue is that the teachers are forced to craft their curriculum around the kids passing the test. So that's why a kid in third grade ends up with 2 hours of Math in class everyday. 2 hours of ELA, and they have to alternate science and History. Which is just crazy. They literally don't have enough time to do science and history everyday.

 My confusion on this subject was that I didn't connect standardized grade school testing to the SAT. And from what I know, Democrats pushed for standardized grade school testing in order to expose the idea that City kids who are predominantly non-white are receiving a substandard education. I have my own theories on that witch involve the kids parents and home life. But now I think they have realized that after 20 years a pushing us that it is actually the home life and instead of admitting that they're going with eliminating testing.

Another interesting development in grade school is the idea of group work. Teachers are recommended to put these kids into what are called mixed ability groups. And then these groups are then supposed to work on school work together. In practice what ends up happening is that the smart kids finish their work and then tutor or give you the answers to the dumb kids. It's a disaster. That's also part of why a lot of schools no longer have advanced classes. Because in advanced classes the smart kids would get pulled out and wouldn't essentially be able to give the answers to the dumb kids. The teachers are not doing this from a malevolent standpoint. It's actually a teaching theory that is called scaffolding. And under the right circumstances it does work wonderfully. What is concerning is when it's used in a way that holds smart kids back in order to prop up less intelligent children.

They literally don't have enough time to do science and history everyday.

My confusion on this subject was that I didn't connect standardized grade school testing to the SAT. And from what I know, Democrats pushed for standardized grade school testing in order to expose the idea that City kids who are predominantly non-white are receiving a substandard education. I have my own theories on that witch involve the kids parents and home life. But now I think they have realized that after 20 years a pushing us that it is actually the home life and instead of admitting that they're going with eliminating testing.

Another interesting development in grade school is the idea of group work. Teachers are recommended to put these kids into what are called mixed ability groups. And then these groups are then supposed to work on school work together. In practice what ends up happening is that the smart kids finish their work and then tutor or give you the answers to the dumb kids. It's a disaster. That's also part of why a lot of schools no longer have advanced classes. Because in advanced classes the smart kids would get pulled out and wouldn't essentially be able to give the answers to the dumb kids. The teachers are not doing this from a malevolent standpoint. It's actually a teaching theory that is called scaffolding. And under the right circumstances it does work wonderfully. What is concerning is when it's used in a way that holds smart kids back in order to prop up less intelligent children.

post.title: An Alarming 1 in 5 Universities Will Fail Due To Lockdowns

body:
Your Idea Maker has a customized description saying what you did. The others just say "had a good development idea".

I could be wrong, but I also don't remember most artisan badges linking to stuff.

In any case, I still think it's not a coincidence that the admins always make sure to give you badges for everything, and that the very same person happens to be selected for a bunch of things. It's not a big deal in and of itself, but it matters because it shows that they have a subconscious bias towards you.

parent.body:
> What about idea maker? That badge was literally created for you.

Wrong. The badges are implemented such that admins can override descriptions and put links while granting them. Internally it's the same badge. As a matter of fact, @unheard is another user with that badge (which got granted for asking to implement search date ranges in the querystring).

> And you also have a customized Artisan badge, which links directly to your pull request...which changes one word of text.

Artisan/Code Contributor badges should be granted for any merged PRs. Also, I made several PRs after that: [#433](https://github.com/ruqqus/ruqqus/pull/433), [#437](https://github.com/ruqqus/ruqqus/pull/437), [#447](https://github.com/ruqqus/ruqqus/pull/447).

> ou basically get a new badge for every pull request you make.

No. Artisan and Code Contributor are the only ones I got for PRs.
